Description: Rim sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery chalice; glaze fired orange-brown; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed below; part of lotus flower in added white outline with added red centre; two white bands below and two more near bottom of sherd; exterior: at rim, billet pattern above zigzag between pairs of lines; below, on left, goose walking right (head, neck, part of wing and body remaining); pendant triangle, roundels and swastika as filling ornament; at right, dividing band consisting of messy vertical hook maeander between pairs of lines, with on the right large squares with maeanders; below, glazed.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as being in the style of the Würzburg chalices, but dated later than those chalices because she considers the style of the drawing to be debased and because of the elementary and isolated interior decoration (Lemos 1991, 72-3). The sherd ought to belong to the later period of the Wild Goat Style since, although the metopal pattern decoration on the exterior surface is typical of the Wild Goat Style, the lotus decoration on the interior, which is absent during this period, is typical in the later reserved Animal Chalice, Grand and Chalice styles. Furthermore, geese are extremely rarely portrayed in the Mature Animal Style.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 73, p. 240, no. 202)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0392) (phase 2)
